facts.text: Civil Appeal No. XXXVIII of 1949 filed.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURIDICTION Civil Appeal No. XXXVIII of 1949.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment of High Court of Judicature at Madras by Gentle C.J. and Patanjali Sastri J.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a Judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras  Gentle C.J. and Patanjali Sastri J.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated August 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: dated August 22, 1947, in a reference under section 66  1  of the Indian

facts.text: Reference under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Re. No. 25 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: dated August 22, 1947, in a reference under section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal  Re . No. 25 of 1946 .

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Fazl Ali J. on December 21, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAzL ALI J.

facts.text: Appeal concerns assessment of appellant to income-tax for year 1942-43.

anchor.surface_text: --This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras on a reference made to it under section 66  1  of the Indian Incometax Act by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in companynection with the assess- ment of the appellant to income-tax for the year 1942-43.

facts.text: Question referred: Whether assessee (Hindu undivided family) is resident in British India under section 4A(b).

anchor.surface_text: The question of law referred to the High Court was as fol- lows -- Whether in the circumstances of the case, the assessee  a Hindu undivided family  is resident in British India under section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellant is karta of joint Hindu family living in Ceylon with wife, son and three daughters, domiciled in Ceylon.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of the case may be briefly stated as follows. The appellant is the karta of a joint Hindu family and has been living in Ceylon with his wife, son and three daughters, and they are stated to be domiciled in that companyntry.

facts.text: Carries on business in Colombo under name General Trading Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: He carries on business in Colombo under the name and style of the General Trading Corporation,

facts.text: Owns house, immovable property and investments in British India.

anchor.surface_text: and he owns a house, some immoveable property and investments in British India.

facts.text: Has shares in two firms at Vijayapuram and Nagapatnam in British India.

anchor.surface_text: He has also shares in two firms situated at Vijayapuram and Nagapatnam in British India.

facts.text: In year of account 1941-42, visited British India on seven occasions, total stay 101 days.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account, 1941- 42, which is the basis of the present assessment, the appel- lant is said to have visited British India on seven occa- sions and the total period of his stay in British India was 101 days.

facts.text: During stays, attended litigation relating to family lands in trial court and court of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: During such stays, he personally attended to a litiga- tion relating to the family lands both in the trial Court and in the Court of appeal.

facts.text: Attended income-tax proceedings for family income assessment at Karaikudi and Madras.

anchor.surface_text: He was also attending the in- companye-tax proceedings relating to the assessment of the family income, appearing before the income-tax authorities at Karaikudi and Madras.

facts.text: On one occasion, obtained extension of time for payment of tax after interviewing authority.

anchor.surface_text: On one of these occasions, he obtained an extension of time for payment of the tax after interviewing the authority companycerned

facts.text: Did not produce file of correspondence with Colombo business.

anchor.surface_text: The other facts relied upon by the income-tax authori- ties were that he did number produce the file of companyrespondence with the business in Colombo

facts.text: Started two partnership businesses in India on 25th February 1942, remained in India after commencement.

anchor.surface_text: so as to help them in determin- ing whether the management and companytrol of.the business was situated in Colombo and he had started two partnership businesses in India on 25th February, 1942, and remained in India for some time after the companymencement of those busi- nesses.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer and Assistant Commissioner held appellant resident under section 4A(b), liable for foreign income.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the facts so stated, the Income-tax Officer and the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax held that the appellant was a resident within the meaning of section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act, and was therefore liable to be assessed in respect of his foreign income.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held non-resident, no act of management/control in British India.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal however came to a different companyclusion and held that in the circumstances of the case it companyld number be held that any act of management or companytrol was exercised by the appellant during his stay in British India and therefore he was number liable to assessment in respect of his income out- side British India.

facts.text: Madras High Court held Tribunal misdirected, control/management not wholly outside British India, family resident.

anchor.surface_text: This view was number accepted by a Bench of the Madras High Court companysisting of the learned Chief Jus- tice and Patanjali Sastri J. They held that the Tribunal had misdirected itself in determining the question of the residence of the appellants family and that on the facts proved the companytrol and management of the affairs of the family cannot be held to have been wholly situated outside British India, with the result that the family must be deemed to be resident ,fin British India within the meaning of section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Family has house at Kanadukathan where mother lives.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the mere fact that the assessee has a house at Kanadukathan, where his mother lives, cannot companystitute that place the seat of companytrol and management of the affairs of the family.

facts.text: During major portion of accounting period (year ending 12th April 1942), appellant controlling businesses in Burma and Saigon.

anchor.surface_text: During a major portion of the accounting period  year ending 12th April, 1942  the appellant was companytrolling the businesses in Burma and Saigon

facts.text: No evidence that control exercised only from Colombo; no correspondence produced.

anchor.surface_text: and there is numberevidence that such companytrol was exercised only from Colombo. No companyre- spondence or other evidence was produced which would show that any instructions were issued from Colombo

facts.text: Unauthorized clerk looking after affairs in British India.

anchor.surface_text: as regards the management of the affairs in British India especially as it was an unauthorized clerk who was looking after such affairs.

facts.text: Onus on assessee to prove control and management wholly outside British India.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that the onus of proving facts which would bring his case within the exception, which is provided by the latter part of section 4A b , was on the assessee.

facts.text: Appellant permanently lives in Colombo, family domiciled in Ceylon.

anchor.surface_text: the head and karta of the asses- sees family who companytrols and manages its affairs permanent- ly lives in Colombo and the family is domiciled in Ceylon.

issues.text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the assessee a Hindu undivided family is resident in British India under section 4A b of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the assessee  a Hindu undivided family  is resident in British India under section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether it can be held that the central control and management of the affairs of the assessees family has been shown to be divided in this case

anchor.surface_text: The question which now arises is what is the result of the application of these principles to this case, and whether it can be held that the central control and management of the affairs of the assessees family has been shown to be divid- ed in this case.

issues.text: whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or outside British India

anchor.surface_text: in order to bring the case under the exception, we have to ask whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or out- side British India.

arguments.claim: Appellant is resident under section 4A(b) and liable for foreign income based on facts of stays and activities in British India.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the facts so stated, the Income-tax Officer and the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax held that the appellant was a resident within the meaning of section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act, and was therefore liable to be assessed in respect of his foreign income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s produced which would show that any instructions were issued from Colombo as regards the management of the affairs in British India especially as it

arguments.court_reasoning: Onus on assessee not discharged; no evidence control wholly outside.

arguments.claim: No act of management or control exercised during stay in British India; non-resident and not liable for foreign income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal however came to a different conclusion and held that in the circumstances of the case it could not be held that any act of management or control was exercised by the appellant during his stay in British India and therefore he was not liable to assessment in respect of his income outside British India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the Income-tax Act, and was therefore liable to be assessed in respect of his foreign income. The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal however came to a

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal misdirected; control not wholly outside.

arguments.claim: Tribunal misdirected itself; control and management not wholly outside British India; family resident under section 4A(b).

anchor.surface_text: This view was not accepted by a Bench of the Madras High Court consisting of the learned Chief Justice and Patanjali Sastri J. They held that the Tribunal had misdirected itself in determining the question of the residence of the appellants family and that on the facts proved the control and management of the affairs of the family cannot be held to have been wholly situated outside British India, with the result that the family must be deemed to be resident in British India within the meaning of section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nt. The same remark must apply to the starting of two partnership businesses, as mere activity cannot be the test of residence. It seems to us that th

arguments.court_reasoning: Narrow view taken by High Court but conclusion correct as onus not discharged.

arguments.claim: Section 4A(b) based on English rule that residence where central management and control abides.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4A  b  runs thus-- For the purposes of this Act---- A Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of persons is resident in British India unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India. [...] the real business is carried on where the central management and control actually abides.

arguments.claim: Control and management means controlling directive power, head and brain, functioning with permanence; wholly allows divided seat.

anchor.surface_text: Control and management signifies, in the present context, the controlling and directive power, the head and brain as it is sometimes called, and situated implies the functioning of such power at a particular place with some degree of permanence, while wholly would seem to recognize the possibility of the seat of such power being divided between two distinct and separated places.

arguments.claim: Normal presumption that HUF resident unless control wholly outside.

anchor.surface_text: The words used in this provision clearly show firstly, that, normally, a Hindu undivided family will be taken to be resident in the taxable territories, but such a presumption will not apply if the case can be brought under the second part of the provision.

arguments.claim: Affairs means those relevant to Income-tax Act and related to income.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, we take it that the word affairs must mean affairs which are relevant for the purpose of the Income-tax Act and which have some relation to income.

arguments.claim: Exception requires seat of direction and control wholly outside British India.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, in order to bring the case under the exception, we have to ask whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or outside British India.

arguments.claim: Wholly allows HUF to have more than one residence like corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, the word wholly suggests that a Hindu undivided family may have more than one residence in the same way as a corporation may have.

arguments.claim: House at Kanadukathan where mother lives does not constitute seat of control.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the mere fact that the assessee has a house at Kanadukathan, where his mother lives, cannot constitute that place the seat of control and management of the affairs of the family.

arguments.claim: 101 days stay for litigation and tax proceedings does not shift seat of control or create second centre.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we inclined in the circumstances of the present case to attach much importance to the fact that the assessee had to stay in British India for 101 days in a particular year. He was undoubtedly interested in the litigation with regard to his family property as well as in the income-tax proceedings, and by merely coming out to India to take part in them, he cannot be said to have shifted the seat of management and control of the affairs of his family, or to have started a second centre for such control and management.

arguments.claim: Starting partnership businesses is mere activity, not test of residence.

anchor.surface_text: The same remark must apply to the starting of two partnership businesses, as mere activity cannot be the test of residence.

arguments.claim: High Court took narrow view by focusing on attendance to affairs during visit.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t be the test of residence. It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b ,

arguments.claim: Onus on assessee to prove control and management wholly outside.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the onus of proving facts which would bring his case within the exception, which is provided by the latter part of section 4A b , was on the assessee.

arguments.claim: No correspondence or evidence produced showing control from Colombo; onus not discharged.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was called upon to adduce evidence to show that the control and management of the affairs of the family was situated wholly outside the taxable territories, but the correspondence to which the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax refers and other material evidence which might have shown that normally and as a matter of course the affairs in India were also being controlled from Colombo were not produced.

holdings.text: A Hindu undivided family is resident in British India under section 4A(b) unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India

anchor.surface_text: Section 4A  b  runs thus-- For the purposes of this Act---- A Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of per- sons is resident in British India unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory rule applied with presumption of residence unless exception proved

holdings.text: The provision in section 4A(b) is based on the English rule that real business is carried on where the central management and control actually abides

anchor.surface_text: the real business is carried on where the central management and control actually abides. It is clear that what is said in section 4A  b  of the Income-tax Act is what Lord Loreburn intended to  1  5 Tax Cas. 198.  2   1876  1 Ex. D. 428, convey by the words where the central management and company- trol actually abides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy from English company law precedents like De Beers case

holdings.text: Control and management signifies the controlling and directive power, the head and brain, situated with permanence; wholly recognizes possible division between places

anchor.surface_text: Control and management signifies, in the present context, the controlling and directive power, the head and brain as it is sometimes called, and situated implies the functioning of such power at a particular place with some degree of permanence, while wholly would seem to recognize the possibility of the seat of such power being divided between two distinct and separated places.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopting and clarifying High Court interpretation of key terms

holdings.text: Normally a Hindu undivided family is presumed resident unless control and management shown wholly outside taxable territories

anchor.surface_text: The words used in this provision clearly show firstly, that, normally, a Hindu undivided family will be taken to be resident in the taxable territories, but such a presumption will not apply if the case can be brought under the second part c,f the provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction creating presumption with exception

holdings.text: Affairs means those relevant for Income-tax Act and related to income

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, we take it that the word affairs must mean affairs which are relevant for the purpose of the Income-tax Act and which have some-relation to income.

holdings.text: To invoke exception under section 4A(b), seat of direction and control must be wholly outside British India

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, in order to bring the case under the exception, we have to ask whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or outside British India.

holdings.text: Wholly suggests Hindu undivided family may have more than one residence like corporation

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, the word wholly suggests that a Hindu undivided family may have more than One residence in the same way as a corporation may have.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation allowing dual residence by analogy to companies

holdings.text: Mere house at Kanadukathan where mother lives does not constitute seat of control and management

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the mere fact that the assessee has a house at Kanadukathan, where his mother lives, cannot constitute that place the seat of control and management of the affairs of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of control test to specific fact

holdings.text: 101 days stay in British India for litigation and tax proceedings does not shift seat of control or create second centre

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we inclined in the circumstances of the present case to attach much importance to the fact that the assessee had to stay in British India for 101 days in a particular year. He was undoubtedly interested in the litigation with regard to his family property as well as in the income-tax proceedings, and by merely coming out to India to take part in them, he cannot be said to have shifted the seat of management and control of the affairs of his family, or to have started a second centre for such control and management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balancing facts against permanence requirement of control

holdings.text: Starting two partnership businesses mere activity, not test of residence

anchor.surface_text: The same remark must apply to the starting of two partnership businesses, as mere activity cannot be the test of residence.

holdings.text: Learned Judges of High Court took narrow view of section 4A(b) by focusing on attendance during visit

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Critique of lower court reasoning though conclusion correct

holdings.text: Onus of proving exception under latter part of section 4A(b) on assessee

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the onus of proving facts which would bring his case within the exception, which is provided by the latter part of section 4A b , was on the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard rule of onus for exceptions

holdings.text: Appellant failed to adduce evidence showing control and management wholly outside; correspondence not produced

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was called upon to adduce evidence to show that the control and management of the affairs of the family was situated wholly outside the taxable territories, but the correspondence to which the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax refers and other material evidence which might have shown that normally and as a matter of course the affairs in India were also being controlled from Colombo were not produced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to discharge onus on facts leads to presumption applying

anchor.surface_text: the law was stated thus by Lord Loreburn in De Beers Howe 1 . A companypany cannot eat or sleep, but it can keep house and do business. We ought, therefore, to see where it really keeps house and does business The decision of Chief

precedents.cited_proposition: A company resides where its central management and control actually abides
precedents.cited_holding: A company cannot eat or sleep, but it can keep house and do business... where the central management and control actually abides

precedents.citation: The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson 2

anchor.surface_text: The decision of Chief Baron Kelly and Baron Huddleston in The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson and The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nichol- son 2 , number thirty years ago, involved the principle that a companypany resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on. Those decisions have been acted upon ever since.

precedents.cited_proposition: a company resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on

precedents.citation: The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nicholson 2

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta Jute Mills v. Nicholson and The Cessna Sulphur Company v. Nichol- son 2 , number thirty years ago, involved the principle that a companypany resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on. Those decisions have been acted upon ever since. I regard that as the true rule,

precedents.cited_proposition: a company resides for purposes of income-tax where its real business is carried on

precedents.citation: Swedish Central Railway Company Limited v. Thompson 1

anchor.surface_text: principles which are number well-established in Eng- land and which will be found to have been very clearly enunciated in Swedish Central Railway Company Limited v. Thompson 1 , which is one of the leading cases on the subject, are --  1  that the companyception of residence in the case of a fictitious person , such as a companypany, is as artificial as the companypany itself,

precedents.case_name: Swedish Central Railway Company Limited v. Thompson
precedents.cited_proposition: locality of residence determined by where is the head and seat and directing power of the affairs of the company
precedents.cited_holding: the exception of residence in the case of a fictitious person, such as a company, is as artificial as the company itself, and the locality of the residence can only be determined by analogy, by asking where is the head and seat and directing power

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment reversed; HUF held non-resident as control and management situated wholly outside British India; Tribunal order restored

Section 66(1) enables the court to make factual holdings on evidence in the reference.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4A  b  runs thus-- For the purposes of this Act---- A Hindu undivided family, firm or other association of per- sons is resident in British India unless the control and management of its affairs is situated wholly without British India.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was called upon to adduce evidence to show that the control and management of the affairs of the family was situated wholly outside the taxable territories, but the correspondence to which the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax refers and other material evidence which might have shown that normally and as a matter of course the affairs in India were also being controlled from Colombo were not produced.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, in order to bring the case under the exception, we have to ask whether the seat of the direction and control of the affairs of the family is inside or outside British India.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.

edges.explanation: Holding on stay for litigation and tax not shifting control overlaps with and addresses the issue of divided control

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we inclined in the circumstances of the present case to attach much importance to the fact that the assessee had to stay in British India for 101 days in a particular year. He was undoubtedly interested in the litigation with regard to his family property as well as in the income-tax proceedings, and by merely coming out to India to take part in them, he cannot be said to have shifted the seat of management and control of the affairs of his family, or to have started a second centre for such control and management.

It seems to us that the learned Judges of the High Court have taken rather a narrow view of the meaning of section 4A b , because they seem to have proceeded on the assumption that merely because the assessee, attended to some of the affairs of his family during his visit t.o British India in the particular year, he brought to himself within the ambit of the rule.
